speech: Phishing is a type of cyber attack where attackers impersonate legitimate institutions.
It usually involves tricking users into revealing personal or financial information.
Most phishing attacks occur through email, but can also come via SMS, phone calls, or fake websites.
Common signs of phishing include misspelled URLs, urgent or threatening language, and unexpected attachments.
Phishing emails often create a sense of urgency to trick users into clicking malicious links.
Some phishing attacks are highly targeted – this is known as spear phishing.
In spear phishing, attackers research their victims to craft more convincing messages.
Whaling is a type of phishing targeting high-level executives or public figures.
Phishing attacks may install malware or ransomware on your device if you click on bad links.
Using two-factor authentication helps protect you even if your credentials are stolen.
Never enter sensitive info like passwords or credit cards through a link from an email.
Hovering over links helps you check where they actually lead before clicking.
Modern phishing attacks may clone websites to look identical to trusted platforms.
Always verify the sender’s email domain carefully – attackers often spoof known brands.
Some attackers use QR codes for phishing, directing you to fake login pages.
Report suspicious emails to your organization or mail provider’s abuse team.
Browser extensions and anti-virus software can help detect phishing websites.
Cybersecurity training reduces the chance of users falling for phishing attempts.
Email providers use spam filters and machine learning to detect phishing attempts.
Being skeptical and cautious with any unexpected communication is your best defense.

data.text: What are common signs of phishing?
How can I avoid phishing scams?
